ai-mn128:1.2_0: at one time the Fortunate One was dwelling near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
ai-mn128:2.1_0: Now at that time the mendicants of Kosambi were arguing, quarreling, and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
ai-mn128:3.1_0: Then a certain monk went to the Fortunate One,
ai-mn128:3.1_1: and after approaching and worshipping the Fortunate One, he stood on one side.
ai-mn128:3.1_2: While standing on one side that monk said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-mn128:3.2_0: “Sir, Kosambi has been arguing, quarreling, and fighting, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
ai-mn128:3.3_0: “Venerable Sir, it would be good if you went to those monks out of compassion.”
ai-mn128:3.4_0: The Buddha consented by remaining silent.
ai-mn128:4.1_0: Then the Buddha went up to those mendicants and said:
ai-mn128:4.3_0: When he said this, one of the mendicants asked the Buddha,
ai-mn128:4.5_0: Let the Buddha, the Lord of the Dhamma,
ai-mn128:4.6_0: remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in the present life.
ai-mn128:4.7_0: We’ll face the consequences of this quarrelling and disputing.”
ai-mn128:4.10_0: For a second time that mendicant said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-mn128:4.12_0: Let the Buddha, the Lord of the Dhamma,
ai-mn128:4.13_0: remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in the present life.
ai-mn128:4.14_0: We’ll face the consequences of this quarrelling and disputing.”
ai-mn128:4.15_0: and a third time the Buddha said to those mendicants,
ai-mn128:4.17_0: For a third time that monk said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-mn128:4.19_0: Let the Buddha, the Lord of the Dhamma,
ai-mn128:4.20_0: remain passive, dwelling in blissful meditation in the present life.
ai-mn128:4.21_0: We’ll face the consequences of this quarrelling and disputing.”
ai-mn128:5.1_0: Then the Buddha robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kosambi for alms.
ai-mn128:5.2_0: He walked for alms and had his meal, and after returning from almsround, he put his dwelling in order. He then took his bowl and robe, and while standing in these verses:

ai-mn128:6.33_0: And go with them, glad and mindful.
ai-mn128:6.34_0: If you do not get a discerning friend,
ai-mn128:6.36_0: then, like a king who flees his conquered realm,
ai-mn128:6.37_0: wander alone like a tusker in the wilds.

ai-mn128:7.1_0: After speaking these verses while standing, the Buddha went to the village of the child salt-miners,
ai-mn128:7.2_0: where Venerable Bhagu was staying at the time.
ai-mn128:7.3_0: Bhagu saw the Buddha coming off in the distance,
ai-mn128:7.4_0: so he spread out a seat and placed water for washing the feet.
ai-mn128:7.5_0: He sat on the seat spread out
ai-mn128:7.7_0: Bhagu bowed to the Buddha and sat down to one side.
ai-mn128:7.9_0: “I hope you’re keeping well, mendicant; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you’re having no trouble getting alms-food.”
ai-mn128:7.10_0: “I’m keeping well, sir; I’m all right. And I’m having no trouble getting alms-food.”
ai-mn128:7.11_0: The Buddha instructed, inspired, and gladdened Bhagu with a teaching. He then got up from his seat and went to the Eastern Bamboo Park.
ai-mn128:8.1_0: At this time Venerable Anuruddha, Venerable Nandiya, and Venerable Kimila were staying at the Eastern Bamboo Park.
ai-mn128:8.2_0: The park keeper saw the Buddha coming off in the distance
ai-mn128:8.3_0: and after seeing (him), he said this to the Fortunate One:
ai-mn128:8.5_0: There are three ascetics from good families staying here, seeking their own benefit.
ai-mn128:9.1_0: Anuruddha heard the park keeper conversing with the Buddha,
ai-mn128:9.2_0: he said this to the giver:
ai-mn128:9.3_0: “Don’t keep the Buddha out, good park keeper!
ai-mn128:9.4_0: Our Teacher, the Blessed One, has arrived.”
ai-mn128:10.1_0: Then Anuruddha went to Nandiya and Kimbila,
ai-mn128:10.1_1: and after going, he said this to venerable Nanda:
ai-mn128:10.2_0: “Come out, Venerables, our teacher has arrived.”
ai-mn128:10.3_0: Then Anuruddha, Nandiya, and Kimbila came out to greet the Buddha.
ai-mn128:10.4_0: One received his bowl and robe, one spread out a seat, and one set out water for washing his feet.
ai-mn128:10.5_0: He sat on the seat spread out
ai-mn128:10.7_0: When they had bowed and sat down,
ai-mn128:10.9_0: “I hope you’re keeping well, Anuruddha and friends; I hope you’re all right. And I hope you’re having no trouble getting alms-food.”
ai-mn128:10.10_0: “Weʼre alright, Blessed One, weʼre getting by. And we have no trouble getting alms-food.”
ai-mn128:11.1_0: “I hope you’re living together in harmony, without dispute, blending like milk and water, and that you regard one another with affection?”
ai-mn128:11.2_0: “Indeed, sir, we live in harmony like this.”
ai-mn128:11.3_0: “But how do you live this way?”
ai-mn128:12.3_0: Whoever lives with such fellow monastics?’
ai-mn128:12.4_0: And I do acts of kindness toward them, by body,
ai-mn128:12.5_0: by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
ai-mn128:12.6_0: and mind, both in public and in private.
ai-mn128:12.8_0: ‘Why don’t I set aside my own ideas and just go along with these venerables’ ideas?’
ai-mn128:12.10_0: Though we’re different in body, sir, we’re one in mind, it seems to me.”
ai-mn128:12.11_0: Nandiya and Kimila then repeated what Anuruddha had said.
ai-mn128:12.13_0: “Sir, I too think in this way.
ai-mn128:12.15_0: Whoever lives with such fellow monastics?’
ai-mn128:12.16_0: And I do acts of kindness toward them, by body,
ai-mn128:12.17_0: by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private.
ai-mn128:12.18_0: and mind, both in public and in private.
ai-mn128:12.20_0: ‘Why don’t I set aside my own ideas and just go along with these venerables’ ideas?’
ai-mn128:12.22_0: Though we’re different in body, sir, we’re one in mind, it seems to me.
ai-mn128:12.23_0: That’s how we live in harmony, appreciating each other, without quarreling, blending like milk and water, and regarding each other with kindly eyes.”
ai-mn128:13.2_0: But I hope you’re living diligently, keen, and resolute?”
ai-mn128:14.2_0: “But how do you live this way?”
ai-mn128:14.3_0: “In this case, sir, whoever returns first from alms-round prepares the seats, and puts out the drinking water and the rubbish bin.
ai-mn128:14.4_0: Whoever returns last from almsround may eat whatever is leftover,
ai-mn128:14.4_1: If he doesn’t want anywhere, he throws it away in water without life, or he has it thrown away.
ai-mn128:14.5_0: Then they put away the seats, drinking water, and rubbish bin, and sweep the refectory.
ai-mn128:14.6_0: If someone sees that the pot of water for washing, drinking, or the toilet is empty they set it up.
ai-mn128:14.7_0: If he can’t do it by himself, he calls someone over by hand signal and they move it together. We don’t speak because of that.
ai-mn128:14.8_0: And every five days we sit together the whole night and talk about the Teaching.”
ai-mn128:14.9_0: That’s how we live diligently, keen, and resolute.”
ai-mn128:15.2_0: But as you live diligently like this, have you achieved any superhuman distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a meditation at ease?”
ai-mn128:15.3_0: “Well, sir, while meditating diligent, keen, and resolute, we perceive both light and vision of forms.
ai-mn128:15.4_0: But before long the light and the vision of forms vanish.
ai-mn128:15.5_0: We haven’t worked out the reason for that.”
ai-mn128:16.1_0: “Well, you should work out the reason for that.
ai-mn128:16.2_0: Before my awakening—when I was still unawakened but intent on awakening—I too perceived both light and vision of forms.
ai-mn128:16.3_0: But before long the light and the vision of forms vanish.
ai-mn128:16.5_0: ‘What’s the cause, what’s the reason why my light and vision of forms vanish?’
ai-mn128:16.7_0: ‘Doubt arose in me, and because of that my immersion fell away.
ai-mn128:16.8_0: When immersion falls away, the light and vision of forms vanish.
ai-mn128:16.9_0: I’ll make sure that doubt will not arise in me again.’

ai-mn128:31.3_0: Now let me develop immersion in three ways.’
ai-mn128:31.4_0: I developed immersion while placing the mind and keeping it connected; without placing the mind, but just keeping it connected; without placing the mind or keeping it connected; with rapture; without rapture; with pleasure; with equanimity.
ai-mn128:32.1_0: When I had developed immersion in these ways,
ai-mn128:32.2_0: To me knowledge and insight arose:
ai-mn128:32.3_0: ‘My freedom is unshakable; this is my last rebirth; now there’ll be no more future lives.’”
ai-mn128:32.4_0: That is what the Buddha said.
ai-mn128:32.5_0: Satisfied, Venerable Anuruddha was happy with what the Buddha said.
ai-mn128:32.6_0: The eighth corruptions of the Teaching is finished.
